list.title: Question 1
list.content:
Which of the following statements does $\textbf{not}$ conform to the definition of a mole?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ 1 mole is the number of H$_{2}$O molecules in 18.02 g of H$_{2}$O
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ 1 mole of Fe has a mass equal to the relative atomic mass of Fe in grams
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ 1 mole of any substance contains 6.02 $\times$ 10$^{23}$ particles
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ 1 mole is the number of H$_{2}$ molecules in 1.01 g of $\ce{H2}$
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
1 mole is the number of $\ce{H_{2}}$ molecules in 2.02 g of $\ce{H_{2}}$. Choices A, B, and C all conform to the definition of a mole.

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
A mass spectrometer was used to determine that the relative ratio by mass of N : O in a molecule containing nitrogen and oxygen is $7 : 16.$ What is the most likely molecule?


- A.$\hspace{1em}\ce{NO}$
- B.$\hspace{1em}\ce{NO2}$
- C.$\hspace{1em}\ce{NO3}$
- D.$\hspace{1em}\ce{N2O5}$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$
Mass ratio is $7:16$ or $14:32$ so it must be $\ce{NO2}.$
Alternatively, assume 7 g N and 16 g O, and convert to moles.  Use the molar ratio to deduce the empirical formula.

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
Which compound has the largest molar mass?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{FeSO4}$
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{K2Cr2O7}$
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{KMnO4}$
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{(NH4)3PO4}$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
M($\ce{K2Cr2O7}$) = (2)( 39.10) + (2)( 52) + (7)(16) = $294.2\,\text{g}\, \text{mol}^{-1}$ The other compounds have lower molar masses compared to $\ce{K2Cr2O7}$.
$\ce{FeSO4}$ ($151.9\,\text{g}\, \text{mol}^{-1}$), $\ce{KMnO4}$ ($158\,\text{g}\, \text{mol}^{-1}$), $\ce{(NH4)3PO4}$ ($149.1\,\text{g}\, \text{mol}^{-1}$)

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
Which of the following statements is true?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ The empirical formula shows only the type of each atom in a molecule.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ The molecular formula is always the same as the empirical formula.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Organic molecules often have different empirical and molecular formulas.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ The empirical formula is always greater than the molecular formula.
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The empirical formula shows the simplest whole-number ratio of elements in a compound. The empirical formula can sometimes be the same as the molecular formula. Choices A, B, and D are all false statements.

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
A molecule has the empirical formula $\ce{CH2}$ and a molecular mass of 56.124 g mol$^{-1}$.  Which is NOT a possible structure for this molecule?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/50987208-e349-47b3-a0eb-7b3a3065b4b5/images/0daecc8f-3722-4fd2-bba7-18fcec633eff/CH0666a.png)


- B. $\hspace{1em}$ ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/50987208-e349-47b3-a0eb-7b3a3065b4b5/images/65b2ddf7-bb96-49a7-9c6c-3040d3b6ef75/CH0666b.png)


- C. $\hspace{1em}$ ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/50987208-e349-47b3-a0eb-7b3a3065b4b5/images/0306563a-4f66-4b48-a167-0b8433a4da5a/CH0666c.png)


- D. $\hspace{1em}$ ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/50987208-e349-47b3-a0eb-7b3a3065b4b5/images/b2b0de5b-790b-42e6-b085-66f24e5c0969/CH0666d.png)
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
The empirical molar mass is approximately 14, so $\dfrac{56.124}{14}$ = 4.
Therefore,the molecular formula is $4\times \ce{(CH2)}$, or $\ce{C4H8}$.
Choice C does not have this formula.

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
Calculate the number of moles in $20.5$ grams of sodium phosphate ($\ce{Na3PO4}$).


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ 0.125 mol
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ 1.25 mol
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ 12.5 mol
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ 125 mol
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The molar mass of sodium phosphate is 163.94 g mol$^{-1}$. Divide the mass (20.5 g) of sodium phosphate by the molar mass to calculate the number of moles of the compound. The rest of the choices are incorrect.

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
Which of the following substances would have the lowest mass?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ 2.50 moles  $\ce{H2O}$
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ 2.50 moles  $\ce{CH4}$
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ 2.00 moles $\ce{SO2}$
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ 2.00 moles $\ce{CO2}$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
$\ce{m(CH_4)} = n \times M = (2.50\,\text{mol})(16.05\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}) = 40.1\,\text{g}$
The other compounds would have a greater mass.
$\ce{m(H2O)} = (2.50\,\text{mol})(18.02\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}) = 45.05\,\text{g}$
$\ce{m(SO2)} = (2.00\,\text{moles})(64.07\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}) = 128.14\,\text{g}$
$\ce{m(CO2)} = (2.00\,\text{moles})(44.01\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}) =88.02\,\text{g}$

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
Refer to the following chemical equation: $\ce{2NO2 (g) -> N2O4 (g)}$
At the same temperature and pressure, $25.0\,\text{cm}^3$ of nitrogen dioxide ($\ce{NO2}$) gas is completely converted to dinitrogen tetroxide ($\ce{N2O4}$) gas. What will be the volume of $\ce{N2O4}$ produced?


- A.$\hspace{1em} 10.0\,\text{cm}^3$
- B.$\hspace{1em} 12.5\,\text{cm}^3$
- C.$\hspace{1em} 25.0\,\text{cm}^3$
- D.$\hspace{1em} 50.0\,\text{cm}^3$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Based on the balanced chemical equation, the number of moles of $\ce{NO2}$ is twice that of $\ce{N2O4}$. Avogadro's law states that the volume of a gas is directly proportional to the number of moles of the gas present $\left(\dfrac{25}{2} = 12.5\right)$.

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
How many molecules are there in 4.80 mol of glucose?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ 2.89 $\times$ 10$^{24}$ molecules
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ 2.50 $\times$ 10$^{24}$ molecules
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ 3.50 $\times$ 10$^{24}$ molecules
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ 2.59 $\times$ 10$^{24}$ molecules
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Use Avogadro's number to interconvert the number of molecules to the amount of molecules in moles:
$N = n \times N_{A}$ $N = 4.80\,\textrm{mol} \times \dfrac{6.02 \times 10^{23}\,\textrm{molecules}}{1\,\textrm{mol}}$ = 2.89 $\times$ 10$^{24}\,\text{molecules}$

list.title: Question 10
list.content: Eugenol is an oily, aromatic liquid extracted from essential oils such as clove and cinnamon. The molecular formula of eugenol is $\ce{C_{10}H_{12}O_{2}}.$ - Calculate the molar mass of eugenol. [1] - Determine the percentage by mass of carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen in eugenol. [3] - Predict the simplest, whole$-$number ratio of the atoms in eugenol. [1]
list.markScheme:
- Molar mass: M(C$_{10}$H$_{12}$O$_{2}$) $= 12.01 \times 10 + 1.01 \times 12 +16.00 \times 2 = 120.1 + 12.12 + 32.00 =\  $ $164.22 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}$ $\checkmark$
- Percentage by mass
  % C = $\left(\dfrac{120.1}{164.22}\right)$ (100)  = 73.13 % $\checkmark$
  % H = $\left(\dfrac{12.12}{164.22}\right)$ (100) = 7.38 % $\checkmark$
  % O = $\left(\dfrac{32.00}{164.22}\right)$ (100) = 19.49 % $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
Divide the total mass of atoms of each element by the molar mass of eugenol and multiply it by 100
- The molecular formula of eugenol is C$_{10}$H$_{12}$O$_{2}$. Therefore, its empirical formula is C$_{5}$H$_{6}$O $\checkmark$  (ratio C : H : O = 5 : 6 : 1)

  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$ 
Divide by the highest common factor (2) to determine the simplest whole number ratio

list.title: Question 11
list.content:
What is the total number of ions in 5.83 g of $\ce{Mg(OH)2}?$
$\mbox{}\\[-15pts]$
$M_r$ of $\ce{Mg(OH)2} = 58.3$ $N_A = 6.0\times 10^{23}\text{\ mol}^{-1}$


- A.$\hspace{1em}0.60 \times 10^{23}$
- B.$\hspace{1em}1.8 \times 10^{23}$
- C.$\hspace{1em}1.2 \times 10^{23}$
- D.$\hspace{1em}6.0 \times 10^{23}$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
First, we need to find moles of $\ce{Mg(OH)2}$ in 5.83 g:
$n_\ce{Mg(OH)2} = \dfrac{m}{M}$ $n_\ce{Mg(OH)2}= \dfrac{5.83\text{\ g}}{58.3\text{\ g mol}^{-1}} = 0.100\text{\ mol}$
To find the total number of ions in 0.100 moles of $\ce{Mg(OH)2},$ we need to consider the formula of $\ce{Mg(OH)2}$ and then calculate the number of ions it dissociates into when dissolved in water. The formula of magnesium hydroxide, $\ce{Mg(OH)2},$ suggests that each formula unit contains one magnesium ion, $\ce{Mg^2+},$ and two hydroxide ions, $\ce{OH-}.$ Since $\ce{Mg(OH)2}$ dissociates into one magnesium ion and two hydroxide ions per formula unit, we have 0.100 moles of magnesium $\ce{Mg^2+}$ ions and 0.200 moles of hydroxide $\ce{OH-}$ ions.
To find the total number of ions, we need to multiply these quantities by Avogadro's number:
$N = n N_A$ $N_\ce{Mg^2+} = (0.100\text{\ mol})(6.0\times 10^{23}\text{\ mol}^{-1}) = 0.60\times 10^{23}\text{\ ions }\ce{Mg^2+}$ $N_\ce{OH-} = (0.200\text{\ mol})(6.0\times 10^{23}\text{\ mol}^{-1}) = 1.2\times 10^{23}\ \ce{ions OH-}$
Adding the two numbers together gives us the answer $1.8\times 10^{23}$ which is option B.

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
What is the percentage by mass of S in the compound sulfur dioxide $\ce{SO2}$?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ 25%
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ 50%
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ 75%
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ 100%
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
% of S = $\left(\dfrac{32.07\,\textrm{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}}{64.07\,\textrm{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}}\right)$ (100) = 50%
The percentage of sulfur in sulfur dioxide is 50%.

list.title: Question 13
list.content:
To make a stock solution of aluminum nitrate $\ce{(Al(NO3)3},$ $M_r = 213.00)$, 10.65 g is dissolved in 150 cm$^3$ of water.
Which calculation below is used to determine the volume, in dm$^3$, of the stock solution needed to make 1.0 dm$^3$ of a 0.050 mol dm$^{-3}$ aluminum nitrate solution?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{10.65 \times 1 \times 0.050}{213.00 \times 0.150}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{10.65}{213.00 \times 0.050 \times 1 \times 0.150}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{0.050 \times 213.00 \times 0.150}{  10.65}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{213.0 \times 0.050}{10.65 \times 1 \times 0.150}$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
First, find the concentration of the stock solution, $C_1$.
$C = \dfrac{n}{V}$ $n = \dfrac{10.65\,\text{g}}{213.00\,\text{g mol}^{-1}}; \hspace{0.2in} V = 0.150\,\text{dm}^3$ $C_1 = \dfrac{10.65}{213.00 \times 0.150}\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}$
For dilutions, we can use the formula
$C_1V_1 = C_2V_2$
which relies on the number of moles in the concentrated stock solution being equal to the number of moles in the dilute, 1.0 mol dm$^3$ solution.
Rearranging to find the volume of the stock solution required, $V_1$,
$V_1 = \dfrac{C_2 \times  V_2}{C_1}$
We are given that $C_2 = 0.050\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}$ and $V_2 = 1.0\,\text{dm}^3.$  Plugging these values in to the expression for $V_1,$ along with the $C_1$ found above, gives
$V_1 = \dfrac{0.050\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}\times 1.0\,\text{dm}^3}{\frac{10.65}{213.00\times 0.150}\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}}$ $V_1 = \dfrac{0.050\times 1.0\times 213.00\times 0.150}{10.65}\,\text{dm}^3$

list.title: Question 14
list.content:
What is the molarity of a solution containing $7.45\,\text{g}$ of KCl dissolved in $250\,\text{cm}^3$ solution?


- A.$\hspace{1em} 0.10\,\text{mol}\,\text{dm}^{-3}$
- B.$\hspace{1em} 0.149\,\text{mol}\,\text{dm}^{-3}$
- C.$\hspace{1em} 0.40\,\text{mol}\,\text{dm}^{-3}$
- D.$\hspace{1em} 0.025\,\text{mol}\,\text{dm}^{-3}$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Molarity is a concentration unit described as the number of moles of solute per unit of volume of solution.
$n = \dfrac{m}{M} = \dfrac{7.45\,\text{g}}{74.55\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}} \approx 0.10\,\text{mol}$ $C = \dfrac{n}{V} = \dfrac{0.10\,\text{mol}}{250\times 10^{-3}\,\text{dm}^3} =  \dfrac{0.10\,\text{mol}}{0.25\,\text{dm}^3} = 0.10 \times 4 = 0.40\,\text{mol}\,\text{dm}^{-3}$

list.title: Question 15
list.content:
What is the approximate mass of $1.81 \times 10^{24}$ aluminium atoms?


- A.$\hspace{1em}9 \textrm{\ g}$
- B.$\hspace{1em}27 \textrm{\ g}$
- C.$\hspace{1em}81 \textrm{\ g}$
- D.$\hspace{1em}181 \textrm{\ g}$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
$n= \dfrac{N}{N_A} = \dfrac{1.81\times10^{24}}{6.02\times10^{23}} = \dfrac{1.81 \times 10}{6.02} =  \dfrac{18.1}{6.02} \approx$ 3
$m = n  M = 3 \times 26.98 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1} \approx 81 \textrm{\ g}$

list.title: Question 16
list.content:
0.0400 moles of magnesium nitrate $\ce{Mg(NO3)2}$ is dissolved in 500 cm$^3$ of water. What is the resulting concentration of all ions in solution?


- A. $\hspace{1em}0.240 \textrm{\ mol dm}^{-3}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}0.0600 \textrm{\ mol dm}^{-3}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}0.160 \textrm{\ mol dm}^{-3}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}0.120 \textrm{\ mol dm}^{-3}$
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
When magnesium nitrate is placed in water it completely dissolves to form its ions:
$\ce{Mg(NO3)2 -> Mg^{2+} + 2 NO3-}$
If the initial amount of magnesium nitrate was 0.0400 mol, the ions will appear in a $1:2$ ratio, 0.0400 mol $\ce{Mg^{2+}}$ and 0.0800 mol $\ce{NO3-}$.  The total amount of ions is sum, $0.0400 + 0.0800 = 0.1200 \textrm{ mol}.$
To find the concentration, use the relationship $C = \dfrac{n}{V}$.  The units of volume must be converted from cm$^3$ to dm$^3$, so we can use the relationship $1000\,\text{cm}^3 = 1\,\text{dm}^3.$
$C = \dfrac{n}{V} = \dfrac{0.1200 \textrm{\ mol}}{500 \textrm{\ cm}^3} \times \dfrac{1000 \textrm{\ cm}^3}{1 \textrm{\ dm}^3} = 0.240\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}$

list.title: Question 17
list.content: Ascorbic acid ($\ce{C6H8O6}$), or vitamin C, is a water-soluble vitamin that is essential for our immune system. - Calculate the number of moles in $2.50\,\textrm{g}$ of ascorbic acid. [1] - Calculate the mass of $1.28\,\textrm{moles}$ of ascorbic acid. [1] - Calculate the number of molecules in $50.0\,\textrm{g}$ of ascorbic acid. [2] - Determine the number of moles of carbon in $225\,\textrm{mg}$ of ascorbic acid [2]
list.markScheme:
- $n = \dfrac{m}{M} = \dfrac{2.50\,\textrm{g}}{176.14\,\textrm{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}}$ = $0.0142\,\text{mol}$ $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  Molar mass of ascorbic acid. $M(\ce{C6H8O6}) = (12.01)(6) + (1.01) (8) + (16.00)(6) = 72.06 + 8.08 + 96.00 = 176.14\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}$
- $m = n\times M = (1.28\,\text{mol}) (176.14\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1})$ = $225\,\text{g}$ $\checkmark$
  $\textit {ALLOW error carried forward from incorrect }$M(C$_{6}$H$_{8}$O$_{6}$) $\textit {calculation in (a)}$
- Number of moles of ascorbic acid in 50.0 grams:
  n = $\dfrac{m}{M} = \dfrac{50.0\,\text{g}}{176.14\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}}$ = $0.284\,\text{mol}$ $\checkmark$
  Number of molecules:
  $N = n\times N_A = (0.284\,\text{mol})(6.02\times 10^{23})$ = $1.71\times 10^{23}$ molecules $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  $N_A$ is Avogadro's number given in the data booklet.
- Number of moles in 225 $\textit{mg}$ of ascorbic acid:
  $n = \dfrac{m}{M} = \dfrac{0.225\,\text{g}}{176.14\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}}$ = $1.277\times 10^{-3}\,\text{mol}$ ascorbic acid $\checkmark$
  Number of moles of carbon:
  $(0.001277\,\text{mol}\ce{C6H8O6})\left(\dfrac{6\,\text{mol}\,\text{C}}{1\,\text{mol}\,\ce{C6H8O6}}\right)$ = $0.00766\,\text{mol}$ C $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  There are 6 moles of carbon in every mole of ascorbic acid. Therefore, multiplying the moles of ascorbic acid by 6 results in obtaining the moles of carbon.

list.title: Question 18
list.content:
Which statement about $\ce{N2O4}$ is incorrect?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$Its empirical formula is $\ce{NO2}.$
- B.$\hspace{1em}$Its percentage composition is 30.45% nitrogen.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$Its percentage composition is 53.32% oxygen.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$Its molar mass is $92.02\,\text{g mol}^{-1}.$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The empirical formula gives the simplest ratio of atoms of each element present in that compound. $\ce{N2O4}$ has two nitrogen atoms for every four oxygen atoms, the simplest ratio is $1:2,$ and the empirical formula is $\ce{NO2}.$
The molar mass of $\ce{N2O4}$ can be determined by adding the masses of each atom.
$M = 2(14.01) + 4(16.00) = 92.02 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}$
The percentage composition must be calculated by assuming one mole of the substance.  For nitrogen:
$\%\ce{N} = \dfrac{m_\ce{N}}{m_{\ce{NO2}}} \times 100\% = \dfrac{2(14.01 \textrm{\ g})}{92.02 \textrm{\ g}} \times 100\%  = 30.45\%$
Since there are only two elements, the mass percent of oxygen is $100 - \%\ce{N} = 69.55 \%.$
This question is categorized as easy as students must be able to understand the difference between empirical and molecular formulae and should also be able to calculate the percentage composition.

list.title: Question 19
list.content: Lipoic acid is an antioxidant that can be taken as a supplement for the body. - Determine the empirical formula of lipoic acid. [4] ElementPercentage Composition by massC46.56%H6.85%O15.5%S31.08% - Calculate the molar mass of the empirical formula of lipoic acid. [1] - If the actual molar mass of lipoic acid is $206.44\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}$, determine its molecular formula. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Convert the percentages of elements into grams. Assume the sample is $100\,\text{g}$.
  C = $46.56\,\text{g}$ | H = $6.85\,\text{g}$ | O = $15.5\,\text{g}$ | S = $31.08\,\text{g}$ $\checkmark$
  Convert the mass of each element into its number of moles. Use the molar mass of each element. $\checkmark$
  $n =\dfrac{m}{M} = \dfrac{46.56\,\text{g}}{12.01\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}}$ = $3.88\,\text{mol}$ C$n =\dfrac{m}{M} = \dfrac{6.85\,\text{g}}{1.01\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}}$ = $6.78\,\text{mol}$ H$n =\dfrac{m}{M} = \dfrac{15.5\,\text{g}}{16.00\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}}$ = $0.97\,\text{mol}$ O$n =\dfrac{m}{M} = \dfrac{31.08\,\text{g}}{32.07\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}}$ = $0.97\,\text{mol}$ S
  Divide all the number of moles by the smallest mole value calculated in the previous step.
  The number of moles of C, H, O, and S will be divided by 0.97. $\checkmark$
  For C: $\dfrac{3.88}{0.97}$ = 4For H:  $\dfrac{6.78}{0.97}$ = 6.99For O:  $\dfrac{0.97}{0.97}$ = 1For S:  $\dfrac{0.97}{0.97}$ = 1
  Round your answers to the nearest whole number. The numbers rounded off will be the subscripts of each element in the empirical formula. The empirical formula of lipoic acid is C$_{4}$H$_{7}$OS. $\checkmark$
- $M(\ce{C4H7OS}) = (4)(12.01) + (7)(1.01) + 16.00 + 32.07 =$  $103.18\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}$ $\checkmark$
- $\dfrac{206.44}{103.18}$ = 2 $\checkmark$
  The molecular formula of lipoic acid is $\ce{C8H14O2S2}$ $\checkmark$
  $\textit{ALLOW error carried forward from incorrect empirical formula calculation in }\text{(a)}$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  To determine the molecular formula, first divide the molar mass of the compound by the molar mass of the empirical formula. Second, multiply the empirical formula by the scaling factor 2 which doubles the number of atoms of each element for the molecular formula.

list.title: Question 20
list.content:
The elemental composition of compound $\textbf{B}$ is given in the table.
$\enskip$Element$\enskip$ $\enskip \textbf{Abundance} \mathbf{\ /\ \% mass}\enskip$ $\ce{C}$75$\ce{H}$25
What is the empirical formula of compound $\textbf{B}$?
Atomic masses (amu) $\ce{C} = 12, \ce{H} = 1$


- A.$\hspace{1em}\ce{C3H}$
- B.$\hspace{1em}\ce{CH}$
- C.$\hspace{1em}\ce{C3H2}$
- D.$\hspace{1em}\ce{CH4}$
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
To determine the empirical formula, assume a 100 g sample of the compound. This would contain 75 g of carbon and 25 g of hydrogen. Converting to moles gives
$n_{\ce{C}} = \dfrac{75 \textrm{\ g C}}{12 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}} = 6.25 \textrm{\ mol}$ $n_{\ce{H}} = \dfrac{25 \textrm{\ g H}}{1 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}} = 25 \textrm{\ mol}$
The simplest whole number ratio is therefore $6.25 : 25,$ which simplifies to $1 : 4.$ This means that for every one atom of carbon there are four atoms of hydrogen, so the empirical formula is $\ce{CH4}$.

list.title: Question 21
list.content:
Which is the correct empirical formula for a compound that is composed of 40% sulfur and 60% oxygen by mass?


- A. $\hspace{1em}\ce{SO}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}\ce{S2O3}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}\ce{SO2}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}\ce{SO3}$
list.markScheme:
D

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
To determine the empirical formula from a mass % composition, first we assume that the sample is 100 g so that the percent composition can be easily converted to mass:
40% sulfur $\longrightarrow$ 40 g sulfur
60% oxygen $\longrightarrow$ 60 g oxygen
Next, these masses are converted into moles:
$40\text{ g S}\times \dfrac{1\text{ mol}}{32\text{ g}} = 1.25\text{ mol S}$ $60\text{ g O}\times \dfrac{1\text{ mol}}{16\text{ g}} = 3.75\text{ mol O}$
From here, the ratio between the atoms is determined:
$\dfrac{\text{mol O}}{\text{mol S}} = \dfrac{3.75\text{ mol}}{1.25\text{ mol}} = 3$
Therefore, there are 3 atoms of oxygen for every 1 atom of sulfur so the empirical formula is $\ce{SO3}.$

list.title: Question 22
list.content:
Which of the following solutions has the greatest quantity of moles of ions in solutions?


- A. $\hspace{1em}200\text{ cm}^3$ of $1.0\text{ mol dm}^{-3}\ce{ NaCl}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}200\text{ cm}^3$ of $1.0\text{ mol dm}^{-3}\ce{ MgCl2}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}100\text{ cm}^3$ of $1.0\text{ mol dm}^{-3}\ce{ NaCl}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}100\text{ cm}^3$ of $1.0\text{ mol dm}^{-3}\ce{ MgCl2}$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
To determine the quantity of moles of ions in solution, each compound must be dissociated to reveal the stoichiometry. Next, the moles of each need to be considered using the equation $n = CV.$ The greatest quantity of ions will be found in the mixtures with the highest volume, so the $100\text{ cm}^3$ answer choices can be eliminated.
For NaCl:
$\ce{NaCl -> Na+ + Cl-}$ $n = (200\text{ cm}^3)\left(\dfrac{1\text{ dm}^3}{1000\text{ cm}^3}\right)(1.0\text{\ mol dm}^{-3})$ $n = 0.20\text{ mol NaCl}$
There is a $1:1$ relationship between the moles of compound and the moles of each ion, therefore there are a total of
$0.2\text{ mol }\ce{Na+} + 0.2\text{ mol }\ce{Cl-} = 0.4\text{ mol of ions}$
For $\mathbf{\mathit{MgCl_2}}$:
$\ce{MgCl2 -> Mg^2+ + 2 Cl-}$ $n = (200\text{ cm}^3)\left(\dfrac{1\text{ dm}^3}{1000\text{ cm}^3}\right)(1.0\text{ mol dm}^{-3})$ $n = 0.20\text{ mol }\ce{MgCl2}$
There is a $1:1$ relationship between the moles of compound and $\ce{Mg^2+}$ and a $1:2$ relationship between the moles of compound and $\ce{Cl-},$ therefore there are a total of
$0.2\text{ mol }\ce{Mg^2+} + 0.4\text{ mol }\ce{Cl-} = \answer{0.6\text{ mol of ions}}$

list.title: Question 23
list.content:
What is the molecular formula of a compound with an empirical formula of $\ce{CH2O}$ and a molar mass of $180.18 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}?$


- A. $\hspace{1em}\ce{CH2O}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}\ce{C6H6O6}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}\ce{C6H12O6}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}\ce{C5H10O5}$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Students must understand the difference between molecular and empirical formulas.
he empirical formula gives the simplest ratio of atoms in a molecule, whereas the molecular formula gives the actual number of atoms present in a molecule. If these two differ, the molecular formula can be deduced from the empirical formula.
Empirical formula: 	$\ce{CH2O}$
$12.01 + 2\times 1.01 + 16.00 = 30.03\,\textrm{g mol}^{-1}$ $\dfrac{180.18\,\textrm{g mol}^{-1}}{30.03\,\textrm{g mol}^{-1}}\approx 6$
Molecular formula (six times the empirical formula): $\ce{C6H12O6}$
This question is categorized as medium as students must differentiate between molecular and empirical formulas and deduce the molecular formula with the periodic table and the molar mass given.

list.title: Question 24
list.content:
What mass of lead (II) carbonate would contain $20.7\, \textrm{g}$ of lead?


- A.$\hspace{1em} 47.4\, \textrm{g}$
- B.$\hspace{1em} 26.7\, \textrm{g}$
- C.$\hspace{1em} 23.5\, \textrm{g}$
- D.$\hspace{1em} 32.7\, \textrm{g}$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The molar mass of lead is $207.2 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1},$ so there is about 0.1 mol Pb. Lead (II) carbonate, $\ce{PbCO3},$ contains 1 atom of lead for every formula unit of lead (II) carbonate: there must be 0.1 mol $\ce{PbCO3}.$ The molar mass of lead carbonate is $267.2 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1},$ so there are 26.7 g.

list.title: Question 25
list.content: A sample of $9.70\,\text{g}$ of an unknown organic compound composed of carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen was burnt with excess oxygen. The combustion produced nitrogen gas, $27.5\,\text{g}$ of $\ce{CO2}$ and $6.57\,\text{g}$ of $\ce{H2O}$. - Calculate the mass of nitrogen produced. [3] - Determine the empirical formula of the compound. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Mass of carbon produced:
  $n_C = \dfrac{m}{M} = \dfrac{27.5\,\text{g}}{44.01\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}} = 0.624\,\text{mol}$
  $m_C = (0.624\,\text{mol})(12.01\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}) =$ $7.49\,\text{g}$ $\checkmark$
  Mass of hydrogen produced:
  $n_H = 2\,\dfrac{m}{M} = 2\,\dfrac{6.57\,\text{g}}{18.02\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}} = 0.729\,\text{mol}$
  $m_H = (0.729\,\text{mol})(1.01\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}) =$ $0.736\,\text{g}$ $\checkmark$
  Mass of nitrogen produced:
  $m_N = 9.70 - (7.49 + 0.736) =$ $1.46\,\text{g}$ $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  There is one mole of carbon atoms in every mole of carbon dioxide produced. The number of moles of carbon dioxide are therefore equal to the number of moles of carbon in the original unknown compound.
  There are two moles of hydrogen atoms in every mole of water produced. The number of  moles of water therefore must be multiplied by 2 to give the number of  moles of H atoms in the original compound.
  The mass of nitrogen in the organic compound is the same as the mass of nitrogen after combustion due to conservation of mass and can therefore be calculate by subtracting the masses of C and H from the total mass of the unknown organic compound.
- $n_N = \dfrac{1.46\,\text{g}}{14.01\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}} =$ $0.104\,\text{mol}$
  Divide the number of moles of each element by the smallest mole value $\checkmark$
  For C:  $\dfrac{0.624}{0.104} = 6$
  For H:  $\dfrac{0.729}{0.104} = 7$
  For N:  $\dfrac{0.104}{0.104} = 1$
  The empirical formula of the compound is $\ce{C6H7N}$ $\checkmark$

list.title: Question 26
list.content:
What is the concentration of sodium ions in a $0.356 \textrm{\ mol dm}^{-3}$ solution of sodium sulfate?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$0.356
- B.$\hspace{1em}$0.712
- C.$\hspace{1em}$0.425
- D.$\hspace{1em}$0.850
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Sodium sulfate ($\ce{Na2SO4}$) dissociates in water, releasing two sodium cations.
$[\ce{Na+}] = 2\times 0.356\,\text{mol dm}^{-3} = 0.712\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}$
This question is categorized as medium difficulty, requiring students to deduce the molecular formula of sodium sulfate and the cation concentration in an aqueous solution.

list.title: Question 27
list.content: A student carried out an experiment to determine the empirical formula of an oxide of manganese. $3.60\,\text{g}$ of the metal was heated in the presence of an excess of oxygen. When the metal reacted completely, $5.64\,\text{g}$ of metal oxide were formed. - Deduce the empirical formula of the oxide. [3] - Suggest an experimental technique the student can use to ensure that the manganese has completely reacted. [1] - A common impurity in manganese is carbon. How would this impurity affect the determination of the empirical formula? [2]
list.markScheme:
- $m_\ce{O2} = 5.64 - 3.60 = 2.04\,\text{g}\ \checkmark$
  $n_\ce{Mn} = 0.0655$ AND $n_\ce{O2} = 0.128\ \checkmark$
  $\ce{MnO2}\ \checkmark$
  Award full marks for correct final answer.
  $\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}$
  The mass of oxygen can be obtained by subtracting the mass of the metal from the mass of the metal oxide.
  $m_\ce{Mn_xO_y} - m_\ce{Mn} = m_\ce{O}$ $5.62\,\text{g} - 3.60\,\text{g} = 2.02\,\text{g}$
  The moles for each of the elements can be obtained by applying the formula; $n = \dfrac{m}{M}$.
  $n_\ce{Mn} = \dfrac{3.60\,\text{g}}{54.94\,\text{g mol}^{-1}} = 0.0655\,\text{mol}$ $n_\ce{O} = \dfrac{2.04\,\text{g}}{16.00\,\text{g mol}^{-1}} = 0.128\,\text{mol}$
  The simplest ratio is obtained by dividing the moles of the substance by the smallest value of moles. This is the empirical formula:
  
  
  - Mn: $\dfrac{0.0655\,\text{mol}}{0.0655\,\text{mol}} = 1$
  - O: $\dfrac{0.128\,\text{mol}}{0.0655\,\text{mol}} = 1.95\approx 2$

  The empirical formula is $\ce{MnO2}$.
- Repeatedly heat and weigh until constant mass is achieved $\checkmark$
  $\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}$
  The mass of the sample is considered to have reached a constant value when the difference between successive weighings is minimal and falls within an acceptable range of experimental error. This indicates that all of the manganese has reacted with oxygen within practical restrictions.
- more oxygen will react per unit mass (to form $\ce{CO2})\,\checkmark$
  the ratio of O to Mn will be greater than 2 $\checkmark$
  $\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}$
  If the manganese sample contains carbon as an impurity, it will also react with oxygen to form carbon dioxide. The additional mass of oxygen bonded to carbon would be incorrectly attributed to the formation of the manganese oxide. This would result in an overestimation of the oxygen content in the final product and an artificially high oxygen-to-manganes ratio. Consequently, the empirical formula of the manganese oxide would be determined incorrectly, potentially showing a higher number of oxygen atoms per manganese atom than is accurate (e.g., $\ce{MnO3}$ instead of $\ce{MnO2}).$

list.title: Question 28
list.content:
Which combination is correct for a sample with $5.00\,\text{mol}$ of $\ce{BaCl2.2H2O}$?


- Amount of chlorine / molNumber of hydrogen atomsMass hydrate / gA.10.00$1.20\times 10^{25}$ $1.22\times 10^3$B.5.00$1.20\times 10^{25}$ $2.44\times 10^2$C.10.00$2.41\times 10^{24}$ $1.22\times 10^3$D.5.00$2.41\times 10^{24}$ $2.44\times 10^2$
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Students must interpret the formula of the hydrated barium chloride.  Each unit of the hydrate contains 2 chlorine atoms.
$n_\ce{Cl} = 2 \times 5.00 \textrm{\ mol} = \answer{10.00 \textrm{\ mol}}$
Similarly, 5.00 moles of the hydrate contain 20.00 moles of hydrogen atoms. The number of H atoms can be deduced by multiplying the amount by Avogadro's number, $N = nN_A$:
$N_\ce{H} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\,\text{mol}^{-1} \times 20.00\,\text{mol} = \answer{1.20\times 10^{25}}$
The molar mass of $\ce{BaCl2.2H2O}$ can be calculated by adding up the mass of each component atom:
$M_r = 137.33 + 2(35.45) + 2[2(1.01) + 16.00] = 244.27$
The mass of $5.00\,\text{mol}$ of $\ce{BaCl2.2H2O}$ can be calculated as $m = n M$.
$ m = 5.00\,\text{mol} \times 244.27\,\text{g mol}^{-1} = 1221.35 \textrm{\ g} = \answer{1.22\times 10^3\,\text{g}}$
This question is categorized as hard since it includes many calculations with some hidden steps to figure out.
Students must interpret the mole concepts and deduce the number of atoms by using Avogadro's number. In addition, the mass of the sample must be calculated with the relative formula mass determination.

list.title: Question 29
list.content:
Water is added to  $200\,\text{cm}^3$ of a $1.50\times 10^{-3}\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}$ HCl solution. The resulting solution has a volume $300\,\text{cm}^3$ greater than the initial. Which statement is correct?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$The amount of solute remains constant, and the final concentration is $6.00\times 10^{-4}\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}.$
- B.$\hspace{1em}$The amount of solute remains constant, and the final concentration is $1.00\times 10^{-3}\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}.$
- C.$\hspace{1em}$The amount of solute decreases, and the final concentration is $6.00\times 10^{-4}\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}.$
- D.$\hspace{1em}$The amount of solute decreases, and the final concentration is $1.00\times 10^{-3}\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}.$
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
This is a dilution problem. The key idea is that when solvent is added, the number of moles of solute stays the same while the total volume increases. First calculate the amount of solute in the original solution using $n = CV.$
$n = 1.50 \times 10^{-3} \textrm{\ mol dm}^{-3} \times 0.200 \textrm{\ dm}^3 = 3.00 \times 10^{-4} \textrm{\ mol}$
After adding $300,\text{cm}^3$ of water, the final volume is $200 + 300 = 500 \text{\ cm}^3 = 0.500 \text{\ dm}^3$.
The concentration of the diluted solution is therefore
$[\ce{HCl}] =  \dfrac{3.00 \times 10^{-4} \textrm{\ mol}}{0.500 \textrm{\ dm}^3} = \answer{6.00 \times 10^{-4} \textrm{\ mol dm}^{-3}}$
